_gram:
[{#at-maniR#} <ls>Uṇ. 4. 152</ls>
said to be from {#an#} to breathe also]
_meanings:
{@--3@} Supreme deity and soul
of the universe, Supreme Soul,
Brahma; {#tasmAdvA etasmAdAtmana AkASaH#}
{#saMBUtaH#} <ls>Up.</ls>; <ls>U. 1. 1</ls>; <ls>Ms. 1. 15</ls>, <ls n="Ms.">12. 24.</ls>

one who pretends to
belong to a higher class than
his own, an impostor, a pretender.

a treaty dictated by the party 
wishing it himself; <ls>H. 4. 121.</ls>

{1} striving to get knowledge (as
an ascetic or {#yogin#}), seeking 
spiritual knowledge; {#AtmArAmA vihitaratayAM#}
{#nirvikalpe samADO#} <ls>Ve. 1. 23.</ls>

a fish supposed
to feed on its young, or on the 
weakest of its species; <ab>cf.</ab> {#matsyA iva janA nityaM#}
{#BakzayaMtiparasparaM .#} <ls>Rām.</ls>

dependent on oneself or on his own
mind.

{2} innate idea, abstract 
knowledge independent of the thing to
be known.

{1} a daughter. 
{2} intellect.
{3} <ab>N.</ab> of a plant ({#mAzparRI#}.)

{1} one who lives by his own
labour; <ls>Ms. 7. 138.</ls>

{3} one who lives by his
wife (<ls>Kull.</ls> on <ls>Ms. 8. 362</ls>).

<ab>N.</ab> of an {#upanizad#} which treats of
the supreme spirit.

{2} loving Brahma or
the Supreme spirit only.

{1} self-executed, done by oneself.
{2} done against one's own self.

{2} one's own course. {# °gatyA#} by
one's own act.

a cave,
the hiding place of an animal,
lair.

{2} victory over oneself,
self-denial or abnegation.

a sage, one who knows 
himself.

{1} the true nature
of the soul or the supreme spirit.

a sage
versed in the Vedānta doctrines.

being constantly
in the heart, greatly endeared to
oneself.

offering oneself (as a living
sacrifice to the deity).

one who constantly seeks for
spiritual knowledge.

<ab>N.</ab> of a work elucidating the
Upaniṣads (consisting of 18 
chapters).

a portion of the Supreme
spirit.

a 
learned man who studies his own nature
and that of the soul (of others) to
secure eternal felicity, one who looks
upon all beings as self; {#sarvaBUtezu#} 
{#cAtmAnaM sarvaBUtAni cAtmani . samaM paSyannAtmayAjI#}
{#svArAjyamaDigaCati#}; <ls>Ms. 12. 91.</ls>

depending on
one's own will; <ls>Ms. 4. 159</ls>, <ls n="Ms. 4.">160</ls>

{2} one's control, 
subjection; {#°SaM nI, °vaSIkf#} to reduce
to subjection, win over.

having control over self, 
self-possessed, self-restrained.

sale of oneself or one's own liberty;
<ls>Ms. 11. 60.</ls>

{1} a wise man,
sage; as in {#tarati SokamAtmavit#}.

knowledge of the soul,
spiritual knowledge; <ls>Ms. 7. 43.</ls>

{2} appropriate, suitable,
good for oneself (as diet &c.).

account of one's own self, 
autobiography.

{2} action
as regards oneself, one's own
state or circumstance; {#vismAyayan#}
{#vismitamAtmavfttO#} <ls>R. 2. 33.</ls>

{3} 
practising one's own duties or occupation.

one's own power or 
ability, inherent power or effort; {#dEvaM#}
{#nihatya kuru pOruzamAtmaSattayA#} <ls>Pt. 1. 361</ls>
to the best of one's power.

worthy of oneself, equal
to oneself; <ls>Ku. 3. 13.</ls>

{3} epithet of
Brahmā, Viṣṇu, or Śiva.

{1} one
who kills his own soul (neglects
its welfare &c.).

{4} a priest in a temple, 

a servant or attendant upon an
idol.
